thinkers.name: Nicolas Rouleau
thinkers.context: Assistant Professor at Wilfrid Laurier University and Tufts University; uses bioengineered tissues to model neural diseases and build minimally cognitive systems.

thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Distinguished Professor at Tufts University and Director of Allen Discovery Center; researches consciousness and cognition across evolved, designed, and hybrid systems.

thinkers.name: Nick Bostrom
thinkers.context: Philosopher who developed concepts of substrate independence relevant to consciousness implementation.

thinkers.name: Frederic Calvo
thinkers.context: Co-author of original paper on plant sentience that prompted this commentary.

thinkers.name: Miguel Segundo-Ort√≠n
thinkers.context: Co-author of original paper on plant sentience arguing for plant cognitive capabilities.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: The capacity to experience as a subject; central topic examining whether it can be instantiated in diverse biological systems including plants.

concepts.name: Animal Sentience
concepts.context: The capacity of animals to experience subjective states; conventionally attributed based on behavioral patterns analogous to humans.

concepts.name: Plant Sentience
concepts.context: Hypothesis that plants possess subjective experience based on goal-directed, anticipatory, and adaptive behaviors similar to animal cognition.

concepts.name: Basal Cognition
concepts.context: Concept that cognitive functions extend beyond neural systems to more fundamental biological and organizational levels.

concepts.name: Multiple Realizability
concepts.context: Philosophical principle that the same function can be implemented by very different physical systems and substrates.

concepts.name: Substrate Independence
concepts.context: The idea that cognitive functions can be achieved without dependence on a particular material or physical medium.

concepts.name: Biological Degeneracy
concepts.context: Principle that structurally dissimilar biological systems can achieve the same functional outcomes through different means.

concepts.name: Theory of Mind
concepts.context: Capacity to attribute mental states to oneself and others; foundational to ascribing sentience by behavioral analogy.

concepts.name: Classical Conditioning
concepts.context: Learning mechanism demonstrated in plants where they learn to avoid neutral stimuli through paired association.

concepts.name: Action Potentials
concepts.context: Electrochemical signaling mechanism found in both animal neurons and plant vascular networks.

concepts.name: Neurotransmitter
concepts.context: Chemical signaling molecules like glutamate used in both animal nervous systems and plants for cellular communication.

concepts.name: Blindsight
concepts.context: Visual responses mediated by subcortical brain regions; example of biological degeneracy in neural function.

concepts.name: Anticipatory Systems
concepts.context: Systems that orient based on predicted reinforcements; demonstrated in plant behavior and goal-directed cognition.

concepts.name: Risk Assessment
concepts.context: Cognitive capacity to evaluate danger and inform behavioral decisions; observed in both animals and plants.

concepts.name: Teleonomy
concepts.context: Goal-directed behavior in biological systems; framework for understanding purposeful action across diverse substrates.

concepts.name: Technological Approach To Mind Everywhere
concepts.context: Framework by Levin for understanding diverse bodies and minds using system-agnostic principles applicable across AI and biology.

concepts.name: Synthetic Morphology
concepts.context: Bioengineering approach to studying cognition through creation of chimaeric and synthetic organisms.

concepts.name: Cybernetics
concepts.context: Study of control and communication systems in machines and organisms; relevant to unified frameworks of consciousness.

frameworks.name: System-Agnostic Approach to Cognition
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Methodological framework that evaluates cognition based on observable behavioral response patterns independent of substrate, applicable across neurobiology, AI, robotics, and materials science.

frameworks.name: Variational Ecology
frameworks.context: Framework connecting physics of sentient systems to ecological principles; cited as relevant to consciousness research.

institutions.name: Wilfrid Laurier University
institutions.context: Institution where Nicolas Rouleau holds position in Department of Health Sciences.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: Home to both Rouleau and Levin; hosts Department of Biomedical Engineering and Department of Biology.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center At Tufts University
institutions.context: Research center directed by Michael Levin investigating consciousness and cognition across biological systems.

institutions.name: Wyss Institute For Biologically Inspired Engineering
institutions.context: Harvard-affiliated research institute where Levin conducts work on biologically inspired systems and consciousness.

institutions.name: Wellbeing International
institutions.context: Organization that published the journal Animal Sentience and maintains the WBI Studies Repository.

institutions.name: Animal Sentience
institutions.context: Peer-reviewed journal on animal cognition and feeling where this commentary was published.

questions.question: Can consciousness and sentience be achieved by biological substrates other than nervous tissue?
questions.context: Central question exploring whether plants and other non-neural systems can possess subjective experience.

questions.question: What are the objective criteria for inferring consciousness in systems that differ substantially from humans?
questions.context: Addresses the methodological challenge of consistently attributing sentience across diverse organisms without direct measurement.

questions.question: Why should plants be denied the possibility of sentience when they display cognitive behaviors analogous to animals?
questions.context: Challenges anthropocentric bias in consciousness attribution and questions the logical consistency of current frameworks.

questions.question: How can a unified framework account for consciousness across biological, artificial, and hybrid systems?
questions.context: Seeks system-agnostic principles applicable to neurobiology, AI, robotics, and materials science.

questions.question: Is consciousness substrate-independent and multiply realizable across different physical and biological systems?
questions.context: Fundamental question about whether consciousness requires specific neural architecture or can be implemented in diverse ways.
